Where we find there to be issues with the structure, or its construction or use, our standard procedure is to give customers  days to remove it as we have done in this case.”

title: family reunited after four years
story: NewsFamily reunited after four years without a single day in the same room togetherPolice officer David Bald finally got to spend the holiday break with his family of ten after years working the Christmas period miles away from homeShareCommentsByGrant Bailey:,  JAN NewsDavid Balds family were reunited - after almost four years apart "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a family were reunited - after almost four years apart. The Bald family, from Milton Keynes, who haven’t been together in the same room for years, were selected from hundreds of ‘long-distance families’ to receive the surprise reconciliation from National Express. Thanks to David Balds work over the festive period as a police officer, he rarely gets to spend the festive period with his parents - who are in their late s - his brother and two nephews. He has worked during every festive season throughout his -year career, including Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and Boxing Day in . Last autumn, National Express put the call-out for families who wouldn’t be able to spend Christmas  together due to their location and travel arrangements. Families from across the country who met these criteria entered the competition to receive free coach travel to bring their disparate clan together over the festive season.  Davids we Sandra entered for the chance to reunite her husband with his family, who live in Edinburgh, at a time of year when this isn’t usually possible. The family of  were reunited in Scotland at the Woodside Hotel in Aberdour, where Sandra and David’s -year-old daughter, Alexandra, who has Downs syndrome, was given a special chance to see her grandparents, uncle and cousins. With David’s work it is tough to arrange a time to make the journey, so it was really a lovely surprise to find out we had been selected. “It has been wonderful to catch up again and for Alexandra to have an opportunity to see her cousins.  “Hopefully it won’t be another three-and-a-half years until we see each other the next time.” National Express arranged all travel for the Bald family and their trip to Aberdour, and funded their festive get-together at the hotel. A spokesperson for National Express said: “We understand that le often takes us far away from home, and can separate us from our hometowns and family. “Christmas is a time for friends and family, but for some its a real challenge to bring the entire clan together. “We are delighted we were able to give the Bald family this small gt to make their Christmas a little bit more special.”

story: NewsFood prices to surge % after year of extreme weather cripples crop growthChristmas offers are about to end and prices are expected to rise by up to ten per cent, according to expertsShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSliced bread loaves have increased in price along with a host of other common shopping staples "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBread and butter is more expensive with sliced loaf prices up nearly a tenth on this time last year. Recent cuts and promotions helped to bring down the average cost of Christmas dinner but now prices are rising for Britain’s shopping staples. Bread and bakery products were hit, mainly because of the weather, according to food industry trade journal The Grocer. Last year’s hot summer led to the smallest wheat crop since . Price rises for a sliced loaf average % but the cost of Hovis bread went up by % and Kingsmill by %. Butter prices have gone up %. title: hulking 6ft 5ins boxer left
story: NewsHulking ft ins boxer left girlfriend fearing for le in brutal attack at her homeCallum Berry, , from Sunderland, has been jailed for the horric attack in the victims homeShareCommentsByRob KennedyCourt ReporterRob KennedyCourt Reporter:,  JAN NewsCallum Berry has been jailed for the horror attack on his girlfriend "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA ft ins boxer left his girlfriend fearing she would die as he choked her in her home. Callum Berry only stopped his horrying attack when he saw flashing blue lights from a police car outside, a court heard. By the time cops arrived he had already kicked her in the head, punched her all over and broken a bone in her face when he started to throttle her. The terried woman said she didnt stand a chance as he carried out the attack which left her an absolute mess. Now the -year-old has been jailed for  months at Newcastle Crown Court, reports Chronicle Live.The woman said in her victim impact statement: I cant believe he has done this.   He is a big, ft in bloke who boxes and does MMA fighting, I didnt stand a chance. He was kicking me in the head while I was on the floor. When he was choking me I honestly thought he was going to kill me, I couldnt breathe. This was a prolonged attack, my face is an absolute mess. Prosecutor Michael Bunch told the court the couple had been out for the evening together last September but Berry was resentful that they were back at her home by pm.   Mr Bunch said he was already highly intoxicated and had started goading his victim for an argument, then broke a bathroom window while trying to climb out. The court heard the woman had shown Berry a cut she received cleaning up the broken glass. Mr Bunch added: She said that then led to the defendant, effectively, going ballistic. He punched her to the face, hard enough to cause her to fall to the floor. Then he started to kick her while she was on the floor. She was crying and trying to get up. He then punched her, in her words, all over, so she was unable to get up before, eventually, being able to to get out of his reach and go to sit on the stairs. The court heard Berry told the woman he would call  but she also rang the police. Mr Bunch said: At that point, realising what she had done, he pulled the living room door from its frame and started to stamp on it. He said he had nothing to lose, came back towards her and placed his hands around her throat. He started to squeeze so she struggled to breathe. She said by this stage she was terried, gasping for breath, trying to beg him to stop but struggling to speak because of the tightness of his grip around her throat. At that point, the police arrived at the scene, blue lights illuminated the room and meant the defendant let go. She fell to the floor. The court heard the victim was taken to hospital, where it was found she had suffered a fracture to a bone in the left side of her face. She has been left with ongoing issues, including nerve damage, which she had been told may take up to  months to completely repair. Berry, of Boston Crescent, Sunderland, admitted causing grievous bodily harm and causing criminal damage in the house during the attack. Recorder Tom Little QC told him: You put your hands around her throat and she struggled to breathe. She said in her victim personal statement she thought she was going to die as a result of what must have been a truly horric incident for her. Fortunately, the police arrived, you saw the blue lights and let go of her throat. Jenner Coxon, mitigating, handed in references about Berrys ordinarily positive character and said he has a supportive family and friends network. Miss Coxon said Berry, who works full-time and also volunteers for charities, was dealing with signicant stresses in his personal le at the time and had been dealing with them himself rather than seeking help. Miss Coxon said Berry had been using alcohol and cocaine at the time of the attack, which he described as disgusting. She added: He is extremely ashamed of what he has done.

title: miscarriages caused low quality sperm
story: NewsMiscarriages caused by low-quality sperm not health of motherExperts are rethinking the causes of recurrent miscarriages after a new study found male partners in miscarriage had sperm with higher levels of DNA-damageShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  JAN NewsRecurrent miscarriage affects around one in  couples "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMiscarriages may be due to the quality of the sperm rather than the health of the mother, a study suggests. The sperm of  men whose shypartners had experienced three or more consecutive miscarriages was compared to that of men whose partners had not had one. Their samples had higher levels of DNA damage, the study found. Recurrent miscarriage affects around one in  couples and is defined as the consecutive loss of three of more pregnancies before  weeks. Until recently it was thought to be caused by health issues with the mother such as infection or immune problems.  Dr Channa Jayasena, lead author of the Imperial College London study, said: “A growing body of evidence suggests sperm health dictates pregnancy health.” DNA damage may be caused by too high levels of reactive oxygen species, molecules that are meant to protect sperm from infection.

title: parents different surnames kids holiday
story: NewsParents with dferent surnames to their kids face questioning at UK airports on family holidaysHeres what you need to remember to pack so your holiday doesnt get off to a bad start...ShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of AudienceEmma Gill:,  AUG Updated:,  JAN NewsGetting to the airport early is a smart move for families - but remember the right documents"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts not uncommon in this day and age for parents to have dferent surnames to their children - but it might ruin your family holidayyou dont adequately prepare for the journey. The government is advising families with dferent surnames to take supporting documentation to airports with them in order to prove they are related. Earlier this year the Home Office shared an image on Twitter urging parents to take birth or adoption certicates on holiday with them in order to speed up the passport control process. They added: Families with dferent surnames may be asked questions to establish their relationship. The tweet was met with a great deal of indignation from parents on the social  and Labour MP Stella Creasy compared the UK to Gilead - a fictional patriarchal dystopia in novel The Handmaids Tale. One Twitter user responded: I am fundamentally against this. My husband and I have dferent surnames. And our son bears my husbands. Not unusual for parents to have dferent surnames in the st Century. Appalling stuff by @sajidjavid and the Home Office. Another wrote: Just to clary women who chose not to take their husbands surname or have children with a partner they are not married to will be subject to increased border measures. This is what freedom looks like under a Tory government  Straight out of Gilead.  Why might families with dferent surnames be questioned at airports  After sharing the original message the Home Office added a follow-up tweet to explain why the procedure is so important, writing: We have a duty to safeguard children and to prevent people trafficking, child sexual exploitation and other crimes. That is why Border Force officers sometimes need to ask additional questions. On the governments website the situation is explained further: Every day thousands of children arrive at the UK border, manyfrom holiday with their family or with family friends. The safety and welfare of every child is of utmost importance to us and sometimes we may ask a few questionsan adult is not the child’s parent, or has a dferent family name. For more information on Border Forces policy, there is a leaflet parents can access on the governments website.  Advice for families travelling with dferent surnames The government advises that,you are travelling with children who have a dferent surname, you may be asked questions at the border to prove your relationship. You can help by bringing with you the following documents:a birth or adoption certicate showing your relationship with the child orce or marriage certicatesyou’re the parent but have a dferent surname from the child a letter from the child’s parent or social worker giving permission for the child to travel with youLast year, a lawyer warned mums and dads they could unknowingly end up embroiled in a child abduction case, be refused past check-in, or turned away at border controlthey fail to take the right documents with them, the Manchester Evening News reported. One of those was Wigan mum Hannah Marshall, who was stopped with her daughter Lilly at London Stansted Airport when they ed from a holiday in Denmark. At the time Hannah, , wasnt married to Lillys dad Scott, so while Lilly had the surname Marshall, Hannahs was still Thomas.  Hannah said While queuing I went to one desk with my daughter and my partner and his mum went to another desk for passport control. They looked at both mine and my daughters passports then asked me how I knew the little girl and when I said it was my daughter they asked why I did not have the same last name. They asked my daughter who I was to her and thats when my partner came over and explained that shes his daughter too and as we werent married she had his last name.  They told us that my partner should have taken her through passport control because I would need to prove she was my daughter. They checked my partners passport to prove she held the same last name and then let us through. It can, however, be dficult for a person to prove they are a childs parent on the spot, unless they are carrying the right documents. David Connor heads up the family department at Woodcocks Haworth and Nuttall Solicitors, who have offices in Bury and Lancashire and says parents need to plan ahead to avoid being caught out. He said: People need to take extra caution when holidaying with children who don’t share their surname as they could unknowingly end up embroiled in a child abduction case, be refused past check-in, or turned away at border control. It’s vital you have the correct documentation to hand or it could derail your trip. For separated families, you’ll need evidence of approval from your child’s other parent, but remember to seek approval from everyone with parental responsibility – this may include grandparents too. He added: You’ll also need a copy of any Child Arrangement Order which proves you have court approval to take the child abroad. It’s vital that all evidence marries up and this is where orced parents are often caught out, particularly women who revert back to their maiden name. A change of name deed will help here, which can be supplied by a solicitor. Take a copy of your child’s birth certicate with you too to prove who you are. You wont need permission from an absent parenttheyre not on the childs birth certicate, butan absent parent has passed away you may be required to take the death certicate with you. If an absent parent doesnt consent to you taking the child out of the country you will need to go to court to try and resolve the matter. For more details about seeking permission to take children abroad, visit the government website here .

story: NewsNightmare Christmas Day lunch see families walk out of pub over complete shamblesOne family left The Birches Head in Sneyd Green, Stoke-on-Trent, to have beans on toast at home insteadShareCommentsByAmi RedfernBradley Jolly:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDiners were furious with their experience at The Birches Head in Stoke-on-Trent "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family say they were left eating beans on toast for Christmas Day lunch after pub booking turned into a complete shambles. But pub manager Annette Townley - who was also responsible for cooking the food - was unable to cope with the demand and says a combination of overbooking by the previous tenants and latecomers turned Christmas Day into a disaster. Stoke Sentinel reports how angry guests called the experience a complete shambles. Kathryn Fairbanks, , was part of a group of  family members expecting to dine that day. Did you have a disastrous Christmas Day lunch  Contact webnews@trinitymirror   She said: We could hear other tables saying that they were waiting to be served, one had been booked in at pm and had only had their starter, and it was pm. Richard Collins discovered the one-year-old, who allegedly wasnt properly dressed and had a dirty nappy, and his family looked after him for  minutes while police tried to find his mum and dad in Torquay, Devon. Mr Collins told Devon Live that his three-year-old daughter played with the boy during the search, and cried when he left their home because she thought he was here for good.   Mr Collins said his family is willing to foster the boy, who remains in police protection. The youngster was found wandering in Main Avenue just before .pm on Wednesday. It took about three hours for police officers to track down his parents while they went house-to-house and put out an urgent appeal. Mr Collins said the boy sat happily in his home where he warmed up and played Lego with his daughter, who was upset when the toddler left with police to be taken to hospital for safeguarding during the search. He said: My little girl cried when the little boy left, as she thought he was here for good. I dont know what will happen to the little boy, but we would be willing to foster him while they sort it out. Mr Collins said he found the toddler wandering in the middle of the road in Main Avenue when he went outside to put something in the bin. He said: He was looking confused. I took his hand and got him to go to the pavement on the opposite side as cars were passing.  Nobody seemed to notice him. I asked two peoplethey knew him. They said no. My partner came out and brought some warm clothing and shoes for the boy as he was looking cold. He didnt seem at all fazed by the situation. We came inside and got warmed up. My little girl sang songs to him. He did not speak much but seemed very happy playing Lego.  My partner changed his nappy as it was dirty. All this took about one-and-a-half hours. The police having no luck finding the parents decided to take him to AE at Torbay Hospital and to seek to put him in care until they could locate the parents and find out what had happened. A local resident, who was at the scene when the boy was found, claimed he had limited speech and he wasnt wearing any shoes or socks.She wrote on social media at the time: I was there when the boy was found. He’s probably  months old. Walking but very limited speech. Didn’t seem at all phased being in a strangers house. Seemed clean but no shoes or socks on. title: inside car future featuring virtual
story: NewsInside the car of the future - featuring virtual reality passengersNissan Research Centre designers say we could be driving with virtual family and friends inside the carShareCommentsByRichard Jenkins:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNew augmented reality is hoped to improve our driving and make the experience more enjoyable "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCar makers have shown a vision of the future – where sat navs beam out avatars that make it look like an animated character is sitting in the passenger seat. The cutting-edge technology is known as ‘Invisible-to-Visible’, or IV, and could entirely change the way we drive. As well as projected avatar passengers demonstrating the best way to drive, the future-tech can even show scenery of a sunny day in the vehicle – when it’s actually raining. The interactive, D display also contains a system using sensors inside and out to anticipate upcoming obstructions. Tetsuro Ueda, an expert leader at the Nissan Research Centre, said: “By helping you see the invisible, IV enhances your confidence and makes driving more enjoyable. “The interactive features create an experience that’s tailored to your interests and driving style so that anyone can enjoy using it in their own way.”  In what Nissan are calling the ‘Metaverse’ – the virtual world that autonomous cars can connect to – it will even be possible for family, friends or others to appear inside the car as three-dimensional, augmented-reality avatars to provide company or assistance. The ‘Metaverse’ maps a -degree virtual space around the car to provide information about things like road and intersection status, visibility, signage or nearby pedestrians.  It can also monitor the people inside the vehicle by using interior sensors to better anticipate when they may need assistance with finding something, or a coffee break to stay alert. Andan obstacle comes up that the car’s automatic systems can’t anticipate, like a fallen tree, control is instantly handed to expert human guides that can remotely offer assistance – like NASA offering guidance on a space mission.  The futuristic tech will be on display at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas from January -. Visitors to CES can experience ‘IV’ at Nissan’s display by putting on a pair of augmented-reality goggles and stepping inside a demonstration cockpit featuring three-dimensional interfaces and displays. Users are guided through scenarios including a tour of a city, receiving help to find an open parking space at a busy mall, seeing a rainy day outside change to a sunny day inside the car, chasing a professional driver avatar to improve driving skills and exploring how IV can see through buildings and around corners.

Many have been told to bolt their rooms shut and stay inside as the winds, waves and torrential rains grow more intense by the hour. The British Foreign Office has this morning issued a warning against Brits travelling to Thailand. Jo Slade, , and her husband Des are stranded on Koh Samui and said the weather was horric. Have you been affected by the storm  Contact webnews@trinitymirror  The mum-of-four said: The weather is horric and all flights today are cancelled. Many people here are stranded. We are due to begin our journey back to UK tomorrow. Fingers crossed it all calms down.  Our complex Centara Villas is right in the beach. We are watching huge waves crashing down and everyone at the hotel is nervous and eager to get back to their UK homes. We can’t believe this time yesterday we were sunbathing on the beach. The noise of the wind is very scary. We’ve been told to stay in our rooms  stay safe. The rain is torrential. While winds are currently recorded at around mph, the Met Office said the sustained gales and vastness of the storm make them strong enough to bring down trees and power lines as well as damage buildings. The heavy rainfall also poses a danger to le with risk of flash flooding, sea surges and landslides.  Mark Robson is also stranded on Ko Yao Noi with his family and said unfortunately, the next few days, we fear the worst. He said they are unable to leave, despite the calm before the storm and have no idea when they will be able tohome. Mark said: Unfortunately the next few days we fear the worst. We cannot leave now when it is calm. No boat can take us. A government ban on all boats in the whole of southern Thailand leaving port means we are here all of today. Tomorrow the storm will be nearer us and the weather will be worse and the likelihood of boats leaving presumably nil. By the time the storm is scheduled to be above us on this tiny little island on Sunday we will be at the mercy of it. We just have to wait. Who knows when we will be able to leave. What will happen here we dont know.  Jamie Rose,  and Vicky Castle, , who live in Folkestone, Kent, flew out for a trip of a letime on December  from London Heathrow, aiming to tour dferent areas over a fortnight. The pair have been in Koh Lanta on the Andaman coast since New Years Eve and have had to scrap their plans of moving on due to impending Storm Pabuk which has cancelled ferries. Vicky, a content editor for Kent Live said: All the locals are pretty chilled about it and just shrug when we asktheyre worried. We were staying in a totally rickety bamboo shack but we quickly hotfooted it to the nearest brick building we could find. Weve now come to a nearby bar resort and half the tourists are on phones looking worried. The others are totally chilled and dont seem to know whats going on.  Natalie Greenwod is trapped on the island of Koh Tao with her partner. She said: At the moment is raining constant and the sea is very rough. Our ferry was cancelled with no way of getting off the island. All ferries stopped and resume on the th however due the demand our earliest opportunity to leave is the th leaving us to face the storm. The Thai Meteorological Department warned of heavy downpours and strong winds in several provinces, including those with popular island destinations such as Samui, Phuket and Krabi.

title: man who child pregnant baby
story: NewsMan who got child pregnant then let baby starve to death jailed for only  yearsDarwin Red Cloud, , from Rapid City in South Dakota, has been jailed after pleading guilty to second degree murderShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDarwin Red Cloud - who also uses the name Darwin Wade "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who got a child pregnant then let their baby starve to death has apologised for not being perfect. Darwin Red Cloud made the remarks as he was sentenced this week to four years in prison following the death of his two-month-old son, Dalton, in . He pleaded guilty to second degree murder at an earlier hearing where pictures of the baby boy with “every bone sticking out” were deemed too distressing to show a courtroom. US attorney Sarah Collins said: There are photos that haunt me and this is one of the cases. Red Cloud, , from Rapid City, South Dakota, was originally charged with sexual abuse of a minor, however the charge was dismissed in a plea agreement as well as first degree murder, felony child abuse and neglect charges, according to US media.  The age of the unnamed mother is not known. It was argued in court he was unaware she was underage, but attorney Ms Collins said there was sufficient evidence he knew her age. The court was also told how Red Cloud had “behaved terribly” in jail and that he had a record of four assaults there, spraying disinfectant on other inmates and threatening staff, reports News Center . But Betsey Harris, representing Red Cloud, argued he had learning dficulties and endured a traumatic childhood, growing up without a father.  She added that he didn’t have the “insights to have a baby and to care for a child” and that the death was the result of a “confluence of circumstances,” News Center  added. Red Cloud told the hearing: I’m sorry. I’m not perfect. I’m a human being whose made mistakes. “I may not be the smartest but I know I can do better. I should’ve paid attention more. I’m sorry. Chief Judge Jeffrey L Viken said this case was “highly unusual” and it was “hard to comprehend the signs were missed by so many”. After the hearing, Red Cloud’s sister, Angie Red Cloud, said she didn’t think the baby showed any signs of emaciation.  She said the mother would “bring him down to the house every other day” and says there were a lot of small babies in their family. Red Cars cousin, Kaitlin Catches, also took to Facebook to defend him, reports the .According to the online publication, she wrote: These reporters wanted to know the bad. But I’m so glad the judge seen the good in my cousin  decided to be lenient. No matter what the records or his dysal baby momma said, HE IS NOT A MONSTER!  I’m glad I took the stand to tell these ppl [sic] who HE IS! I don’t want my cousin to take the full responsibility but he is because he knows he was a parent. Although he isn’t the only parent, he chose to own up to it. The prosecutor was trying to make him sound like a monster  give him no less than years. I’m so thankful he will be home soon  able to get the help he needs. Our nightmare is over!!

title: alloa shock must not happen again says dundee uniteds rachid bouhenna
story: Rachid Bohenna has admitted Dundee United cannot afford any more “mistakes” like Saturday’s shock defeat at Alloathey are to remain in the thick of the Championship promotion race.The French-born Algerian was as stunned as anyone as the Tangerines battled hard to get themselves into a winning position at the Indodrill Stadium, only to waste all their good work by conceding two late goals to the Wasps.And he knows as United battle to close a seven-point gap to second-tier leaders Ross County, they cannot afford any more such slip-ups.On a tight pitch, and despite dominating possession for most the  minutes, Bouhenna and his team-mates had to battle hard to go ahead via a spectacular Callum Booth free-kick an hour into the proceedings.Having been so much on top, when the ball hit the back of the net, it looked odds on Robbie Neilson’s team would go on and take three points to keep them in touch with top pair County and Ayr United.For a while it even looked like the all-important second goal would come and Bouhenna knows United created enough openings to get it.More than that, though, the -year-old felt United should have been in a position to make sure that one goal they’d fought so hard for would prove enough to take the points back to Tannadice.That it wasn’t has left him a frustrated man this week.“Saturday was a very big disappointment for us,” he said.“When you are one up in the second half of a game like this, you must keep this advantage. We controlled the game and had chances to score the second.“We didn’t and then we concede two goals and that is not good. If we want to be top of this league we cannot repeat this mistake.”Painful as the unexpected defeat was, he believes what’s vital now is United put the disappointment of what was only a second defeat since Neilson took charge in October, behind them as quickly as possible.And with home games against Partick Thistle and Dunfermline coming up over the next two Saturdays, he wants the focus to be on what lies ahead and not what’s just gone.“We now just have to think about the next game. We have two games coming now at home and we must think about that and make sure we win them.“Alloa was a very big disappointment but there is still half of the season for us to play and we must put things right. We must keep going and be strong for the rest of the season.“We have been good in most home games and we must make sure that continues.”Since his arrival near the end of the summer transfer window on a two-year contract at Tannadice, Bouhenna has impressed as a hard-tackling centre-half who can also play when he is moving forward with the ball at his feet.Saturday past, however, saw him moved into a midfield holding role and despite the result, put in an impressive performance.For him that change of role was about doing what was needed for the team.“I have played before some games in the midfield. Fraser Fyvie was injured and I will play there because you must always do what is needed for the team.“It was not a surprise because when I came here I played some games in midfield and when the manager asked me to play there I was happy to do it for the team.“I have played some games there during my career. Centre-back is my best position, of course, but I knew I could help the team there and I did it.”

title: at least 10 cops line dundee street after disturbance at home
story: Police officers were called to Mains Road in Dundee following a disturbance at a house.A witness said the street was “lined” with police cars near to its junction with Dens Road at around am on Wednesday.Officers were seen running towards a close before carrying bags out of the property.A number of residents in the block said they were aware of the police presence but were unsure what had happened. The witness said at least  police officers were around a man as he was removed from the close.A spokesman for Police Scotland confirmed two people had been involved in a “heated argument” before both parties contacted the police.He said: “Police Scotland attended an address on Mains Road, Dundee, at am in response to a reported disturbance.“Two people were involved in a heated argument which resulted in both parties contacting police.“Both were given suitable advice regarding the matter and no formal action was taken.”

title: bottom of table dundee need some guts says martin woods
story: Midfielder Martin Woods expects Dundee boss Jim McIntyre to put together a team of fighters this month that the Dens Park faithful can get behind as they stare a drop battle in the face.The -year-old, who is expected to extend his short-term deal with the club, was part of the Ross County rebuild job done by the current Dark Blues gaffer back in -.McIntyre’s new-look side kept the club in the top-flight and Woods is backing his boss to repeat that feat.By the end of January,  new players had come in with nine departing Dingwall before embarking on a epic run of eight wins and a draw from nine games between February and the end-of-season split – with Woods kicking off the run with an opener against Motherwell on Valentine’s Day.He said: “There’s no hiding that the gaffer wants to make a lot changes, get people in he can trust and that know the style of play he wants.“The previous manager recruited in a certain way and it doesn’t suit the current manager, so I expect a lot of changes and we’ll be a lot stronger team come the end of January.“January was huge for us at Ross County, we found a team and went on a crazy run.“It was really, really good but it’s a tough league and the players who come in have to hit the ground running.“They need to have the right character and the manager will be looking to do that with his recruitment.“It doesn’t always click straight away but that’s why the manager will be looking for certain types, for people who are reliable.”The Dark Blues finished off a dreadful year with a woeful performance in a - home defeat to St Johnstone on Saturday which only made the need for a raft of changes to the squad clearer to see.Woods added: “When the chips were down on Saturday it wasn’t good enough, it was poor, lacking energy, lacking bravery. Bringing in the right people who have been there and done it, have got the drive to take the ball and make something happen and can make the flash that gets us back into the game will make us a lot stronger.”Woods has made a real impact on the side since penning a short-term contract that expired after the weekend loss.Even in that defeat, the former Partick man drew the only positive shout from the crowd as he squared up to a couple of St Johnstone men with the yell ‘at least he’s showing a bit of fight’ coming from the home support.“I would agree with that,” Woods said.“That was out of pure frustration. The crowd in the main have been absolutely brilliant and that’s just not me trying to be the good guy and get everybody up.“I think they’ve been really good for the position the club is in.“They just want people battling, people at it, giving their lot – that’s the least you should be giving. I think those will be the types the manager is after in January, giving what he is like as a guy and what he demands of people.“He’ll want people to go and give their lot, it might not be perfect every week, but they’ll give their full lot and they’ll have some guts.”Though he’s not signed yet till the end of the season, Woods says he’s keen to stay on.He added: “We spoke after the game and that’s ongoing just now, we’ll see what happens.“I’ve loved my time here, the fans have been great with me, the boys have been great, too, getting me right in the mix straight away.“The manager has been really good, I know what I’m getting from him but I think he needs a bit of help so, hopefully, he gets that this month and gets a few boys in who are up for the challenge.”

title: brexit dundee shops and cafes to stay open later to mark eu departure
story: A one-off night of late openings for cafes and traders in the city centre will take place on March .The evening of late trading has been co-ordinated by city development convener Lynne Short after claims by City Centre and Harbour Community Council that Dundee’s early evening nightle was non-existent.Ms Short’s choice of date for the “European-style” hours is deliberate, since it is the last day the UK is officially part of the European Union.She said: “The businesses are keen and the council is aiming to work with others to add things to do.“The community council has endorsed it too – it is keen to build links with the business community and sees it as a great opportunity to help each other out.“Why shouldn’t Dundee show its European credentials  We voted to stay and we have a massive European history and population.”

title: closed dundee pub could be given new lease of life by heineken firm
story: Fresh plans have been unveiled to give a new lease of le to a once-popular city pub.Star Pubs and Bars, which owns The Mercantile in the city centre, said the firm is confident the venue will be taken over this year.The company, a subsidiary of brewing giants Heineken, said talks are ongoing with interested parties hoping to take on the Commercial Street boozer.The Mercantile closed in August  for a makeover with the intention of reopening once it was complete, however, the doors remained shut and the search is still on for a licensee.The Tele previously revealed that Heineken was prepared to inject £, into The Mercantilea licensee came forward.But the plans have now been revised in a bid for the pub to host live entertainment.New designs released on the company’s website highlight a more spacious interior which would include a DJ booth, a stage and a privatearea, with the pub simply renamed “Smith’s”.The previous plan was for a “modern industrial bar” named A. Smith Merchant.A spokeswoman for Star Pubs and Bars said: “We have revised the refurbishment scheme which includes more glass in the front and a more open, spacious interior.“We currently have several parties interested in taking it on and we are confident the scheme will go ahead in .”An advert for potential licensees notes that the venue could benefit from added footfall in the city centre thanks to the arrival of the VA and the Waterfront development.The factsheet states: “The Mercantile will be transformed into a premium bar which is able to trade strongly throughout the day.“The refurbished pub will be well-placed to accommodate office workers for coffee in the mornings, shoppers and office workers for lunch and an after-work crowd in the early evening. It will also become part of the circuit later at night through live entertainment.“A DJ booth with ladder access will be installed and the bar servery will be moved closer to the dining area. A stage will be added, which will be visible throughout the premises.”Heineken said in  that it hoped to pump £, into The Mercantile and The Gunners Bar in Broughty Ferry as part of a joint investment.

title: dundee planning swoop for ross county captain marcus fraser
story: Dundee are planning a swoop for Ross County skipper Marcus Fraser.Manager Jim McIntyre’s plans to reshape the Dark Blues squad this month are set to ramp up over the coming days and the -year-old defender is one on the Dens gaffer’s radar.Former Celtic kid Fraser was made captain at Victoria Park over the summer ahead of their bid for an immediateto the Premiership following last season’s relegation.He’s played  times for the Staggies this campaign as they’ve put themselves on track to do just that as they lead the second-tier title race.His current deal with the Highland club expires in the summer, however, which could pave the way for Dundee to do a deal this month to prevent the Staggies losing him for nothing.A swap deal for Dens stalwart Cammy Kerr has been mooted, though the full-back is himself free to speak to other clubs this month with his own contract ending in the summer.And the desire to stay in the top flight,a new offer from the Dark Blues isn’t forthcoming, is likely to see Kerr weigh up his options.With his side rock bottom of the Premiership during the winter break, Jim has repeated the need to bring in the “right types” to get the side out of relegation trouble – something he did in similar circumstances at County.And that could mean moving for players he’s worked with before knowing exactly what they will bring with October signing Martin Woods already an example of that.With Dundee already short of centre-backs, a move for former Scotland U  man Fraser could be made sooner rather than later.

title: dundee set to make sensational move for dundee united striker craig curran
story: Dundee United striker Craig Curran could be set for a sensational crossing of Sandeman Street with Dundee boss Jim McIntyre keen to add him to his striking options.Curran was signed by the Dens gaffer at Ross County and, with the Dark Blues in a similar position to the one the Staggies were in back in , McIntyre wants the -year-old to aid veteran Kenny Miller in the striking stakes.The Liverpudlian scored  times over four seasons for the Highland outfit but still has two-and-a-half years on his deal at Tannadice.A step back up to the Premiership to play for his old gaffer might just suit him, evenit means making the switch between city clubs.Meanwhile, Glen Kamara may have played his last game for Dundee with a raft of clubs lining up to look at the Finnish international.English Premier League battlers Cardf City are the latest to have looked at the central midfielder with boss Neil Warnock admitting this week he’s interested in Kamara.The Tele revealed last month that fellow-Welsh side Swansea City had sent scouts to run the rule over the former Arsenal kid.And in the summer he’d also been linked with both Celtic and Rangers, Hearts and Hibs, as well as English Championship clubs including Frank Lampard’s Derby County.With his contract ending at the end of the season, the -year-old can speak to other clubs regarding a pre-contract move.However, the playing style under new manager McIntyre isn’t suited to the former Arsenal man’s talents and a January switch would suit both parties.The club have confirmed Marcus Haber has been released after his loan move to Falkirk was cut short.

title: dundee united transfer boost as owner mark ogren hires sporting director
story: New Dundee United owner Mark Ogren has made his first move to improve the club’s fortunes by hiring former agent Tony Asghar as the club’s new sporting director.The American took control of the Tannadice outfit midway through December and has moved quickly to install Asghar, who helped broker the deal between the Minnesota-based businessman and former owner Mike Martin and director Jimmy Fyffe.Former police officer Asghar owns Revolution Global Sports Consulting Ltd, which has interests in the United States and has worked for leading clubs across Europe.Coming in at the start of the transfer window could be a boost to manager Robbie Neilson’s plans to freshen up his squad as they look to reignite their Championship title challenge.Last weekend’s - defeat at Alloa left the Tangerines seven points behind leaders Ross County in the race toto the top flight.Neilson hasn’t hidden his desire to improve the squad he took over in October saying after the defeat to Jim Goodwin’s strugglers that some of his charges weren’t up to the challenge of a title fight.Names of those he’s keen to bring in, however, have been hard to come by.One who has been mentioned is Raith Rovers winger Daniel Armstrong.The former Wolves winger penned a short-term deal at Stark’s Park in November.That expires after the Scottish Cup clash with Dunfermline on January , however.Rovers boss John McGlynn said: “The club has done everything it possibly can and what will be will be. The club can do no more now.“I would say that Dan has been very, very good for Raith Rovers and Raith Rovers have been very good for Dan.”

title: ex dundee defender jack hendry to leave celtic on loan
story: Former Dundee defender Jack Hendry is set to leave Celtic on loan this month.Since departing Dens for a club-record fee last January, Hendry has struggled to command a regular starting spot at Parkhead and the club are keen to give him game time where.Ato the Dark Blues, however, is unlikely with clubs down south lining up to take Hendry on a temporary deal.Jack Ross’s Sunderland head the pack with fellow League One challengers Bradford and Portsmouth also keen to add the former Wigan man to their ranks.The -year-old hasn’t featured for Celtic since the - Europa League defeat to RB Salzburg on October .In his short spell at Dundee, Hendry made just  appearances before Celtic secured him in a seven-figure deal.

title: man who built diy bomb caused explosion in dundee with materials in hair gel tub
story: A former Royal Marine facing jail after admitting making a DIY bomb and dealing CS spray caused an explosion with materials in a hair gel tub.Allan Peach, , caused a mass evacuation of the area surrounding his flat on Carlochie Place on September  where officers found a cache of weapons.When police foiled his operation, Peach said: “I am not a bad man. I’m just trying to make ends meet.”Peach pleaded guilty today to making a pipe bomb, and having materials to make nine other devices. He also admitted possessing CS spray for sale.Just six years earlier he was jailed for causing an explosion at flats on Cullen Place with materials in a hair gel tub.The High Court in Glasgow heard how one of Peach’s neighbours struck up a friendship with him.After being invited round for a coffee, he noticed Peach – an agriculture student at DA College – had canisters of CS spray in his living room, which he asked his friend to take photos of.Soon after, it was apparent Peach was advertising the canisters for sale. Police received intelligence that he was concerned in the supply of CS spray at his and his mum’s addresses.Officers attended Carlochie Place at .am on September  but there was no reply, with a joiner called out to gain entry.They discovered CS spray canisters in the living room and a lockfast safe along with a dark powder and metal pipes in his bedroom.At .am, Peach ed home and was detained while a search was carried out. He said he had a key for the safe which contained CS spray and a pipe bomb which was manufactured with a copper pipe and a fuse attached to the end.Explosive ordnance officers were drafted in and made the device safe. The court heard that g of powder, found to be potassium nitrate and magnalium, was contained in the device.Experts deemed it to be “poorly-made and low explosive”.Further material was found in Peach’s bedroom which was deemed to be enough for him to make another nine pipe bombs, while  canisters of CS spray were recovered.The court heard that Peach was suffering from severe depression and anxiety at the time, as well as heart problems.After being taken to police headquarters, he became tearful and feared he would be going to prison for “maybe longer this time”.Solicitor advocate Chris Fyffe said he would reserve mitigation until the completion of criminal justice social work reports.Sentence was deferred until January . Peach was remanded in custody meantime.

title: marcus haber one of two dundee players leaving the club
story: Marcus Haber has today left Dundee.The striker signed for the club in  and spent the first half of this season on loan with Championship side Falkirk, playing against Dundee United last month.He scored  goals in  appearances for the Dark Blues.Midfielder Grant Nelson, who signed for the club on a short-term deal in October, as part of the reserve squad, has also left the club at the end of his contract.A Dundee statement said: #We would like to thank Marcus and Grant for their efforts while with the club and wish them all the best for the future.#

title: nicky low set for dundee return with queen of the south
story: Dundee’sto action after the winter break will see a familiar face on the opposing side after Nicky Low signed for Queen of the South.The Dark Blues kick off their  action on January  with a Scottish Cup fourth-round tie against the Doonhamers at Dens Park.Immediately after the draw the buzz was around former Dee favourite Gary Harkins’as part of Gary Naysmith’s side.His move to Partick earlier this week, though, ended that.Twenty-six-year-old Low, however, has stepped in to take that mantle and he’s expected to make his debut for the Dumfries side in Saturday’s league clash at Inverness.After a successful period at Irish side Derry City where he was named Player and Player’s Player of the Year in  and featured in the Europa League, Low has decided toto Scotland with Queens.Naysmith said: “Nicky had a few offers from other Championship clubs so I am pleased he has agreed to sign for us. He is a good age, , and has played in the Premier league here in Scotland for both Aberdeen and Dundee so he has a fair bit of experience.”He added: “We’ll have Nicky available at Inverness.“I’m still hopeful of getting one or two in, with Gary Harkins going it frees up his money.“I’ve also got to speak to Callum Semple and Adam Frizzell about extending their loans. I’ve had brief discussions with Sheffield United and Kilmarnock about that but I need to speak to them.“I like to have my players in ASAP but I have five, six enquiries in for players just now but I have to wait on their parent clubs.”Motherwell defender Barry Maguire has joined on loan till the end of the season.

title: three out as dundee boss jim mcintyre vows to make things better
story: Dundee manager Jim McIntyre has vowed “it will get better” after he watched his side limp into the winter break.The Dens gaffer has already begun to pull apart the squad of players he inherited back in October, just hours after his side were dismantled by St Johnstone in a - home defeat.Adil Nabi and Andy Boyle’s short-term deals have ended, with the latter ing to parent club Preston North End.Also heading back to his club is Calvin Miller after the club cut short his loan deal that originally lasted till June.That’s expected to be only the start, however, as Jim puts together a side he feels can get the Dark Blues off the bottom of the Premiership.He said: “Everyone knows we have to get players in and this underlines it again.“The team needs strengthened, it’s as clear as day that’s what has to happen.“There is quite clearly a freshness needed to bring to the squad and the board know that, they’re not daft.“We need to get the right types now and I am very confident I’ll get the backing we need.”Tommy Wright’s Saints controlled the contest from the outset, with Scott Tanser’s cross finding the net within the opening minute before Liam Craig sealed the points in the second half with more poor Dundee defending proving costly.And the Dens gaffer says it was “a sore one to take” after going unbeaten in their previous four home games.He added: “We were poor and were second best throughout.“The first goal in any game is crucial and we have a chance to clear our lines but don’t.“We were nowhere near it on Saturday.“We were lucky it was only two.“If you are seeing players not committed, not seeing that fighting spirit and seeing people disappear – because clearly that is what happened – then it’s very frustrating.“It’s a sore one to take because we have given stronger performances to our punters lately but that wasn’t good enough.“The supporters are rightly disappointed with us as a group on Saturday because it wasn’t good enough.“But it will get better.”Talks have begun to extend midfielder Martin Woods’ short-term deal which ends today to the end of the season.

title: x factor star dermot oleary to make special visit to va dundee for historic event
story: X Factor star Dermot O#Leary is to make a special visit to VA Dundee for an historic event.The talent show presenter is to unveil the shortlisted nominees for this year#s National Television Awards on Monday lunchtime.There will also be a surprise in store for O#Leary, , who will present the awards live on ITV from .pm on Tuesday January .With more than  million votes recorded last year alone, the event marks the opening of the final public vote to choose the  NTAs winners.The winners of the  publicly voted categories will be announced at the main showm which takes place in London#s O Arena.The shortlisting event is the first of its kind at the VA Dundee and will put the Waterfront attraction, which opened in September last year, in the frame for future events of national importance.It is the latest boost to the standing of the city, which in the past  months has been named as a must-visit destination by Lonely Planet, Wall Street Journal and The . Dundee was also named on National Geographic UK’s Cool List .The event is being brought to Dundee in a partnership involving NTA, VisitScotland and their EventScotland team.
